quest_title: An electron is moving in electric and magnetic field. It will gain energy from
explanation_txt:
Magnetic force on a moving electron acts perpendicular to the direction of velocity. So magnetic field do not contribute energy to the moving electron. On the other hand, electric force acts in the direction of velocity imparting energy to electron.

Thus, an electron gains energy from electric field only.
question_plain_title: An electron is moving in electric and magnetic field. It will gain energy from

Thus, an electron gains energy from electric field only.

quest_title: A galvanometer has a resistance of 7\(\Omega\) and gives a full scale deflection for a current of 1.0A. How will you convert if into a voltmeter of range 10V?
explanation_txt: \(R=\cfrac{V}{i g}-G=\cfrac{10}{1}-7=3 \Omega\)

ans3_plain_text: 17 in series
ans4_plain_text: 30 in series

quest_title: Thermocouple is a device for the measurement of
explanation_txt: Thermocouple works on the principle of Seeback effect. Once a temperature difference is produced at two junctions of dissimilar metals, a difference in electric potential at two junctions is produced. This electric potential is helpful to determine the temperature difference of two bodies in contact with the junctions.
question_plain_title: Thermocouple is a device for the measurement of
explanation_plain_text: Thermocouple works on the principle of Seeback effect. Once a temperature difference is produced at two junctions of dissimilar metals, a difference in electric potential at two junctions is produced. This electric potential is helpful to determine the temperature difference of two bodies in contact with the junctions.

\(B=\cfrac{6 \mu_{0} i}{2 \pi \sqrt{3} l} 2 \times \sin 30^{\circ}=\cfrac{\sqrt{3} \mu_{0} i}{\pi l}\)

quest_title: Equation of the hour hand at 4 O’ clock is
explanation_txt:
Since the hour, minute and second hands always pass through origin because one end of these hands is always at origin. Now at 4 O’ clock, the hour hand makes angle in fourth quadrant. So the equation of hour hand is

\( \begin{array} { c } { y = m x \Rightarrow y = - \cfrac { 1 } { \sqrt { 3 } } x } \\ { \Rightarrow x + \sqrt { 3 } y = 0 } \end{array} \)

quest_title: In an atom of an element 2K, 8L, 8M and 2N electrons are present. The total number of p electrons will be
explanation_txt:
Electronic configuration of the atom is 

\(\underbrace{1s^2}_{2}\underbrace{2s^22p^6}_{8}\underbrace{3s^23p^6}_{8} \underbrace{4s^2}_{2}\)   

Total no of p-electrons = 6 + 6 = 12

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: Which of the following does not reflect the periodicity of the elements
explanation_txt:
Bonding behaviour, electronegativity and ionization energy follow periodic trends on moving left to right or top to bottom on periodic table.

But no such trends is obtained in case of neutron-proton ratio.

quest_title: The equation of the plane through (1, 2, 3) and parallel to the plane \(2x+3y-4z=0\) is :
explanation_txt:
Plane parallel to the plane \(2x+3y-4z=0\) is \(2x+3y-4z+k=0\) .....(i)

Also plane (i) is passing through (1, 2, 3)

\[{\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise4pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu\raise1pt\hbox{.}\mkern1mu} (2)\, (1)+(3)(2)-(4)(3)+k=0\Rightarrow k=4\]

Required plane is \(2x+3y-4z+4=0\).

quest_title: A \(\gamma\) rays from radioactive source is measured with a count meter. The initial count is 1200 counts/min. When a sheet is placed infront of counter then it shows 3186 counts/min. The absorption coefficient of sheet is 1100m\({}^{-1}\) then thickness of sheet is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{C}_{0} \mathrm{e}^{-\mathrm{\mu x}}\)
or, \(3186=1200 \mathrm{e}^{-\mu \mathrm{x}}\)
or, \(\mathrm{e}^{\mu \mathrm{x}}=\cfrac{1200}{3186}\)
or, \(\mu \mathrm{x}=\ln \left(\cfrac{12000}{3186}\right)\)
or, \(\mathrm{x}=\cfrac{1}{1100} \ln \left(\cfrac{12000}{3186}\right)=1.2 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{m}\)
\(=1.2 \mathrm{mm}\)

explanation_plain_text:

quest_title: Beats are produced due to superposition of two progressive wave trains of nearly equal frequencies. If the ratio of the maximum of minimum intensity is 49, then the ratio of amplitudes of the two progressive wave trains is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} & \cfrac{I_{\max }}{I_{\min }}=\left(\cfrac{a_{1}+a_{2}}{a_{1}-a_{2}}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \, & \cfrac{a_{1}+a_{2}}{a_{1}-a_{2}}=7 \\ \Rightarrow \, & a_{1}+a_{2}=7 a_{1}-7 a_{2} \\ \Rightarrow \, & 6 a_{1}=8 a_{2} \\ & \cfrac{a_{1}}{a_{2}}=4 / 3 \\ & a_{1} : a_{2}=4 : 3 \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The product of atomic mass and specific heat of any element is a constant, approximately 6.4. This is known as:
explanation_txt:
Dulong and Petit's law states the product of specific heat and the atomic mass of an element in the solid state is approxoximately equal to \(6.4 .\)

Limitations of Dulong and Petit's law,

  • This law is applicable to elements which are in solid state.
  • This law Is applicable to the heavier element. It is not applicable to lighter elements having high melting points.
  • This law gives approximate atomic mass.
question_plain_title: The product of atomic mass and specific heat of any element is a constant, approximately 6.4. This is known as:

quest_title: Which of the following salt does not get hydrolysed in water ?
ans3_txt: \(C H _ { 3 } C O O N a\)
explanation_txt:
Only salts of (weak acid + strong base) and (strong acid + weak base) get hydrolysed (i.e., show alkalinity or acidity in water). \(KClO_4\) is a salt of strong acid and strong base therefore it does not get hydrolysed in water.

\(K C l O _ { 4 } \rightleftharpoons K ^ { + } + C l O _ { 4 } ^ { - } ; H _ { 2 } O \rightleftharpoons O H ^ { - } + \quad H ^ { + }\)

quest_title: Conc.\(H _ { 2 } S O _ { 4 } \) is diluted
ans1_txt: By adding water in \( H_{ 2 } S O_ { 4 }\)
ans2_txt: By adding \( H _ { 2 } S O _ { 4 }\) in water
ans3_txt: By adding glacial acetic acid in \( H _ { 2 } S O _ { 4} \)
explanation_txt:
Concentrated \(H_2SO_4\) is diluted by adding the conc. \(H_2SO_4\) in the water drop by drop with constant stirring because it is an exothermic reaction and by doing so heat is generated slowly and dissipated in the atmosphere.

If water is added to conc. \(H_2SO_4\), the reaction occurs in explosive way with the release of large amount of energy.
question_plain_title: Conc. is diluted
explanation_plain_text:
Concentrated is diluted by adding the conc. in the water drop by drop with constant stirring because it is an exothermic reaction and by doing so heat is generated slowly and dissipated in the atmosphere.

If water is added to conc. , the reaction occurs in explosive way with the release of large amount of energy.

quest_title: A block of mass 2 kg is placed on the floor. The coefficient of static friction is 0.4. If a force of 2.8 N is applied on block parallel to the floor, the force of friction between floor & block is
explanation_txt:
Limiting force of friction,

\(\left(F_{f}\right)=\mu R=0.4 \times 2 \times 10=8 \mathrm{N}\)

Force applied = 2.8 N

\(\therefore\) Frictional force = 2.8 N
question_plain_title: A block of mass 2 kg is placed on the floor. The coefficient of static friction is 0.4. If a force of 2.8 N is applied on block parallel to the floor, the force of friction between floor & block is
explanation_plain_text:
Limiting force of friction,

Force applied = 2.8 N

Frictional force = 2.8 N

quest_title: A sphere of radius 1cm is placed at focus of concave mirror of diameter of aperture 60cm. If solar constant is 0.14w/cm\({}^{2}\) then the maximum temp of sphere in atmosphere of 27\({}^{0}\)c is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{S} \times \cfrac{\pi d_{m}^{2}}{4}=\sigma 4 \pi \mathrm{r}^{2}\left(\mathrm{T}^{4}-\mathrm{T}_{0}^{4}\right)\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{T}^{4}=\cfrac{\mathrm{Sd}_{\mathrm{m}}^{2}}{4 \times 4 \times \sigma \mathrm{r}^{2}}+\mathrm{T}_{0}^{4}\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{T}=\left(\cfrac{\mathrm{Sd}_{\mathrm{m}^{2}}}{16 \sigma \mathrm{r}^{2}}+\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{o}}^{4}\right)^{1 / 4}\)

quest_title: A real image of an object placed at a point in front of a concave mirror is twice it's size. When object is moved 5cm towards mirror, the magnification becomes 3 times. The radius of curvature of mirror will be
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)m = \( \cfrac{v}{u} \)

\(\quad\)or, v = 2u

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{uv}{u + v} = \cfrac{2u^{2}}{2u + v} = \cfrac{2u}{3} \)

\(\quad\)Again, m'\(\) = \( \cfrac{v'}{u - 5} \)

\(\quad\)v'\(\) = 3(u - 5)

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{u'v'}{u' + v'} = \cfrac{\left(u - 5\right) 3\left(u - 5\right)}{\left(u - 5\right) + 3\left(u - 5\right)} \) = \( \cfrac{3}{4} \)(u - 5)

\(\quad\)Now, \( \cfrac{2u}{3} \) = \( \cfrac{3\left(u - 5\right)}{4} \)

\(\quad\)or, 8u = 9u - 45

\(\quad\)or, u = 45cm

\(\quad\)f = \( \cfrac{2 \times 45}{3} \) = 30cm

\(\quad\)r = 2f = 60cm

quest_title: A diverging lens is placed on the axis of a concave mirror of focal length 15cm at a distance of 15cm from the mirror. An object at 30cm from the lens an inverted image is formed with itself. The focal length of lens is
explanation_txt:
For concave lens

\(\mathrm{u}=-15 \mathrm{cm} \quad \mathrm{v}=30 \mathrm{cm}\)

\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{\mathrm{uv}}{\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{v}}=\cfrac{(-15) \times 30}{-15+30}=-30 \mathrm{cm}\)

quest_title: The set of values of \(x\) for which the expression \( \cfrac { \tan 3 x - \tan 2 x } { 1 + \tan 3 x \tan 2 x } = 1\) , is
explanation_txt:
\( \cfrac {\tan3x - \tan2x}{1 + \tan3x \tan2x} = 1 \\ \implies \tan(3x - 2x) = tanx = 1 \)

So, \( x = n\pi + {\pi \over 4} \)

But these values of \(x\) makes \( \tan2x \) infinity. Hence they can't be acceped as solution.

So the answer is (a).

quest_title: The number of non-zero integral solutions of the equation \(| 1 - i | ^ { x } = 2 ^ { x }\) is
explanation_txt:
Since, \( |1 -i| = \sqrt{1+1} = \sqrt 2 \), the given equation is \( 2^{x \over 2} = 2^{x} \)

This implies, \( x = 2x \) or \( x= 0 \).

Therefore, the number of non-zero integral solutions is nil or zero

quest_title: If \( \Delta = a ^ { 2 } - ( b - c ) ^ { 2 } \), where \( \Delta \) is the area of triangle \( ABC \), then \(\tan A\) is equal to
explanation_txt:
\( \begin{array} { l } { \Delta = 2 b c - \left( b ^ { 2 } + c ^ { 2 } - a ^ { 2 } \right) } \\ { \Delta = 2 b c ( 1 - \cos A ) = 2 b c \cdot 2 \sin ^ { 2 } \cfrac { A } { 2 } } \quad \dots (i) \\ { \Delta = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } b c \sin A = \cfrac { 1 } { 2 } ( b c ) 2 \sin \cfrac { A } { 2 } \cos \cfrac { A } { 2 } } \\ { \Delta = b c \sin \cfrac { A } { 2 } \cos \cfrac { A } { 2 } } \quad \dots (ii) \end{array} \)

\(\begin{array} { l } { \tan \cfrac { A } { 2 } = \cfrac { 1 } { 4 } = t , \{ \mathrm { by } ( \mathrm { i } ) \text { and } ( \mathrm { ii } ) \} } \\ { \tan A = \cfrac { 2 t } { 1 - t ^ { 2 } } = \cfrac { 8 } { 15 } } \end{array} \)

quest_title: The value of \[I=\int _{\, 0}^{\, 1}\, x\, \left|x-\cfrac{1}{2} \right|\, dx \] is
explanation_txt: \[ \begin{align} I & =\int _{0}^{1}x\, \left|\, x-\cfrac{1}{2} \, \right|\, dx \\ & =-\int _{0}^{1/2}x\left(x-\cfrac{1}{2} \right)+\int _{1/2}^{1}x\left(x-\cfrac{1}{2} \right) \, dx \\ & =\int _{0}^{1/2}\left(\cfrac{1}{2} x-x^{2} \right)\, dx+\int _{1/2}^{1}\left(x^{2} -\cfrac{1}{2} x\right)\, dx \\ & =\left(\cfrac{x^{2} }{4} -\cfrac{x^{3} }{3} \right)_{0}^{1/2} +\left(\cfrac{x^{3} }{3} -\cfrac{x^{2} }{4} \right)_{1/2}^{1} \\ & =\left(\cfrac{1}{16} -\cfrac{1}{24} \right)+\left(\cfrac{1}{3} -\cfrac{1}{4} +\cfrac{1}{16} -\cfrac{1}{24} \right) \\ & =\cfrac{1}{8} .\end{align} \]
